reviewText: This was a lovely animated holiday special. They don't make very many Halloween specials anymore. It's as if American society wants to let it die, which is a real shame because Halloween is my favourite holiday. I absolutely love this movie. It was made in 1993 but it has a feel to it that makes it seem far older. It just has an old fashioned quality to it that I find strangely comforting.It's based on the story by Ray Bradbury, author of The Martian Chronicles and Fahrenhiet 451 and he even narrates it, which I love. Bradbury is one of my favourite authors. Sure this film has a few slightly dark moments but it's actually very educational and at the same time heart warming.

reviewText: Only Ray Bradbury could create childhood again and that joy and fun every Halloween. And this movie manages to capture the novel beautifully. I can't recommend this enough for people of all ages. The animation and music and story all mesh together beautifully. Every year, I read and watch The Halloween Tree. This coming October, I will do so with a heavier heart now that Ray Bradbury has passed away. I hope someone is able to finally give this a proper dvd treatment so even more people can enjoy it.

reviewText: Finally this came out on DVD. My children remember this (they're now 21 and 24) fondly from the days of broadcast TV when I, one year, taped a bunch of Halloween specials for them onto a VHS tape .. and one of them was The Halloween Tree.  Well - that VHS tape was watched again and again, I'd used a low resolution to get 6 hours of specials onto 1 tired tape - LOL - had no idea that one of the specials (The Halloween Tree) would become so beloved by them that they'd remember it long after that tape had degraded and had to be thrown out.  We no longer own a VCR, so any tape version we found over the years really was pretty useless...we couldn't watch it anyway .. so to our great delight this year, we looked again and sure enough it finally has been released on DVD.  As my daughter would say, "YAY!!!!!"

reviewText: Let me start out by saying that "The Halloween Tree" is one of Bradburys greatest works, and a book I never fail to read every Halloween.  Now on to the movie. I wanted to like it i really dd, since I love the book. Sadly however the producers took the masterpeice and created this... which hardly resembles the book.  Yes Bradbury did the narriation, I don't know why but he did, Lenord did a great job, and the movie is in ways entertaining, BUT it sways fully from the book.  It's obvious that it was written with the intent to please all kids, which is show by the adding of a girl to the group.  The whole point of Pip is that he "hated girl more than the rest of the gang put together" so the includng of one tears the essence of what the book is. It's fine that they added a little girl, BUT it destroys what the book is, so therefore much as it pains me I'll have to give it only a three star rating.
summary: I hate to say this but...

reviewText: I'm so glad this came out on DVD. It's not perfect by any means but Leonard Nimoy's narration and vocal work as Monkshroud, guiding the kids through the history of traditional Halloween elements is a wonderful October slice of mood. The animation is decent old-style hand cells and has some marvelous imagery and the storyline is smooth, leading through a lot of what could've been very boring history without a glitch. Rather educational while still being a great piece of the season.

reviewText: First let me warn you, this is a little too spooky for kids 7 and under. But it won both an Emmy Award, and an award from the Film Advisory Board. The film is based on a story by Ray Bradbury, and he narrates the movie. The movie is very different than the book, but than what movie isn't? The scary "Moundshroud" character keeps you guessing as to whether his intents are good or evil. He is wonderfully voiced by Leonard Nimoy, and if you have never heard him voice animated films, not only is he really good but you can't tell it is him!In the story 4 kids,(3 boys and 1 girl) are preparing for Halloween night and find that their buddy Pippin is being taken away in an ambulance. No one seems to know whats wrong with him, and the kids seem lost without him as he is the one they all look up to. A mysterious character shows up by the name of Moundshroud, who tells them that his spirit has been taken by ghosts of Halloween past and they must come with him to capture Pippins spirit and return it to its body. But can they trust him, as it seems he has his own secret motive for capturing Pippin. Each of the kids is dressed as a classic Haloween character Moundshroud takes them across the world and through time itself to discover the origin of that classic Halloween costume character. For example the hunt for the mummys origin  leads them to ancient Egypt and its dark secrets. The skeleton takes them to old Mexico for "Day of the Dead" celebrations. The Witch takes them back to the bards of England. They also learn what real friendship truly means, and must freely give a huge personal sacrifice if they want to save the soul of their friend.This movie is bigger in story than it seems, and my wife has watched this tape about 6 times. The animation is good, very fluid, good character design. The movie will keep you guessing until the end. Suspenseful, imaginative, and educational without looking like it is trying to be.UPDATE: Thanks to E. Von Ray for alerting me, this has finally been released in DVD in September 2010 after it's original VHS release in 1996. The new DVD is only a DVR print on demand copy by Warner Archives, so we will see how the quality is. Some DVD players do not like the DVR format. If I buy one I will update here, and hang on to my VHS copy for now.

reviewText: Halloween is a very special holiday for me, one that I've always loved sharing with my children and now my grandchildren.  But far too many of the books and videos associated with it are too gory and nasty for kids, or are sappily sugar coated.The Halloween Tree manages to incorporate suspense and the history of our holiday in a way that my grandchildren greatly enjoyed.  It's a good tale of friendship.

reviewText: This is a fine adaptation of one of Ray Bradbury's most enchanting books, and with Ray's narration and the incomparable Mr. Spock himself as Mr. Moundshroud, this is a first class production.The literally haunting journey through Time into the history of Halloween across various cultures is both highly educational and spookily entertaining.Through it all, Ray's reverence for Life itself and the importance of love, friendship and self-sacrifice just shines like a jewel in this thought-provoking masterpiece.The beautiful, uplifting ending that made the book such a classic is well captured here, as all ends well, and everyone grows from the experience, as it should be in Life.This is a powerful and intriguing movie that is a feast for kids and adults alike.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This was my son's favorite halloween movie when he was a kid.  It's an enjoyable, and rather spooky tale written by the great Ray Bradbury who also doubles as the story's narrator.  Voice talents include Leonard Nimoy as the evil Moundshroud.  It tells the story of four kids dressed up for Halloween as a witch, skeleton, werewolf, and mummy who travel both around the world and also throught time to save the life of their friend and also learn the true meaning of Halloween.  The traditonal animation is first rate as is the voice talent.  While it does provide it's lesson for kids the movie is a bit spooky so very young ones may get scared so be warned.  It was fun, scary, and eductional.  A real Winner.  I wish it played on TV regularly.
